review.title: Entropy and Syntropy in the Context of Five-Valued Logics
review.abstract: This paper presents a five-valued representation of bifuzzy sets. This representation is related to a five-valued logic that uses the following values: true, false, inconsistent, incomplete and ambiguous. In the framework of five-valued representation, formulae for similarity, entropy and syntropy of bifuzzy sets are constructed.

sections.heading: 6 Similarity, Entropy and Syntropy of Bifuzzy Sets
sections.text: The uncertainty of fuzzy sets is known as blur. A measure of blur is entropy (16) mentioned for the first time by Zadeh. Kaufman [10] has proposed measuring a degree of blur of any fuzzy set. De Luca and Termini [13] have introduced some requirements for the entropy of fuzzy sets. Szmidt and Kacprzyk have extended these requirements from fuzzy sets to intuitionist fuzzy sets. Kosko [11] has proposed measuring the blur of fuzzy sets. We have extended these requirements from fuzzy sets to intuitionist fuzzy sets.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, a method for presenting polyvalent knowledge was presented and a pentaval logic based on five values was presented: true, false, incomplete, contradictory and ambiguous. On the basis of this logic, we obtain new representations for bifuzzy sets. These new representations provide formulas for entropy and syntropy of bifuzzy sets. This approach provides a vector structure with three components for entropy and two components for syntropy. However, the proposed measure is in line with the classical entropy for standard fuzzy sets.
